nexttext:
where $t$ is the amplitude of the nearest-neighbor hopping matrix (taken as a unit of measure for energy, i.e. $t=1$, in the remainder of this work); $c_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}$ ($c^{\dagger}_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}$) destroys (resp. creates) an electron of spin ${\sigma}$ in a Wannier orbital centered at site ${\mathbf{r}}$; $n_{{\mathbf{r}},{\sigma}} = c^{\dagger}_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}c_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}$ is the number of electrons of spin ${\sigma}$ at site ${\mathbf{r}}$, and $n_{\mathbf{r}}=n_{{\mathbf{r}},\uparrow}+n_{{\mathbf{r}},\downarrow}$.
The three vectors ${\mathbf{e}}_{1,2,3}$ link a site of sublattice A with its three nearest neighbors on sublattice B, and are oriented at $120^\circ$ of each other.
$\mu$ is the chemical potential, $U$ the on-site repulsion and $V$ the Coulomb interaction between electrons located on nearest-neighbor sites.

On the $U$-$V$ plane and at half-filling, model \eqref{eq:model} has antiferromagnetic (AF) and charge-density-wave phases separated by a normal phase~\cite{Faye:2014}. 
The parameters appropriate for graphene sheets~\cite{Wehling:2011} should fall in the latter phase, in the approximation where interactions beyond nearest-neighbor sites are neglected.
At large $U$, the model can be used for other materials, for instance the compound $\mathrm{In}_3\mathrm{Cu}_2\mathrm{V}\mathrm{O}_9$, which is known from experiments to be antiferromagnetic~\cite{Yan:2012}.


\begin{figure}
\centerline{\includegraphics[scale=0.75]{hexa}}
\caption{(Color online) Tiling of the honeycomb lattice by 6-site clusters (gray shading) used in VCA.
The three colors (red, green, blue) of the links correspond to the three different phases of the bond triplet pairing in the Kekul\'e pattern defined as {$p$+$ip$-K}\ in the text.
The A and B sublattices are indicated, as well as the three elementary vectors ${\mathbf{e}}_{1,2,3}$.}
\label{fig:hexa}
\end{figure}



\subsection{The variational cluster approximation}

In order to probe the possibility of superconductivity in model \eqref{eq:model}, we use the variational cluster approximation (VCA) with an exact diagonalization solver at zero temperature~\cite{Dahnken:2004}.
This method has been applied to many strongly correlated systems in connection with various broken symmetry phases, in particular superconductivity~\cite{Senechal:2005,Aichhorn:2006}.
For a detailed review of the method, see Refs~\cite{Potthoff:2012fk,Potthoff:2014rt}.

Like other quantum cluster methods, VCA starts by a tiling of the lattice into an infinite number of (usually identical) clusters. 
In this work, we will use the 6-site cluster shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:hexa}.
In VCA, one considers two systems: the original system described by the Hamiltonian $H$, defined on the infinite lattice, and the {\it reference system}, governed by the Hamiltonian $H'$, defined on the cluster only, with the same interaction part as $H$.
Typically, $H'$ will be a restriction of $H$ to the cluster (i.e., with inter-cluster hopping removed), to which various Weiss fields may be added in order to probe broken symmetries.
More generally, any one-body term can be added to $H'$.
The size of the cluster should be small enough for the electron Green function to be computed numerically.


The optimal one-body part of $H'$ is determined by a variational principle. More precisely, the electron self-energy ${\bm{\Sigma}}$ associated with $H'$ is used as a variational self-energy, in order to construct the following Potthoff self-energy functional~\cite{Potthoff:2003b}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle H=-t\sum_{{\mathbf{r}}\in A,\sigma,j}\left(c^{\dagger}_{{\mathbf%
{r}},\sigma}c_{{\mathbf{r}}+{\mathbf{e}}_{j},\sigma}+\mathrm{H.c}\right)-\mu%
\sum_{\mathbf{r}}n_{{\mathbf{r}}}\\
\displaystyle+U\sum_{{\mathbf{r}}}n_{{\mathbf{r}},\uparrow}n_{{\mathbf{r}},%
\downarrow}+V\sum_{{\mathbf{r}}\in A,j}n_{{\mathbf{r}}}n_{{\mathbf{r}}+{%
\mathbf{e}}_{j}}" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>t</mi><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>σ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><msubsup><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mo>†</mo></msubsup><msub><mi>c</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>𝐞</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>𝐫</mi></munder><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>𝐫</mi></msub></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>𝐫</mi></munder><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>,</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>,</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>𝐫</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>𝐞</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext:
The quantities ${\mathbf{G}}'$ and ${\mathbf{G}}_0$ above are respectively the physical Green function of the cluster and the non-interacting Green function of the lattice. 
The symbol $\xi$ stands for a small collection of parameters that define the one-body part of $H'$. 
${\mathrm{Tr}}$ is a functional trace, i.e. a sum over frequencies, momenta and bands, and $\Omega'$ is the grand potential of the cluster, i.e. its ground state energy, since the chemical potential $\mu$ is included in the Hamiltonian.
${\mathbf{G}}'(\omega)$ and $\Omega'$ are computed numerically via the Lanczos method at zero temperature.

The Potthoff functional $\Omega[{\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi)]$ in Eq.~\eqref{eq:omega} is computed exactly, but on a restricted space of the self-energies ${\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi)$ that are the physical self-energies of the reference Hamiltonian $H'$.
We use a standard optimization method (e.g. Newton-Raphson) in the space of parameters $\xi$ to find the stationary value of $\Omega(\xi)$:
prevtext:
where $t$ is the amplitude of the nearest-neighbor hopping matrix (taken as a unit of measure for energy, i.e. $t=1$, in the remainder of this work); $c_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}$ ($c^{\dagger}_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}$) destroys (resp. creates) an electron of spin ${\sigma}$ in a Wannier orbital centered at site ${\mathbf{r}}$; $n_{{\mathbf{r}},{\sigma}} = c^{\dagger}_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}c_{{\mathbf{r}},\sigma}$ is the number of electrons of spin ${\sigma}$ at site ${\mathbf{r}}$, and $n_{\mathbf{r}}=n_{{\mathbf{r}},\uparrow}+n_{{\mathbf{r}},\downarrow}$.
The three vectors ${\mathbf{e}}_{1,2,3}$ link a site of sublattice A with its three nearest neighbors on sublattice B, and are oriented at $120^\circ$ of each other.
$\mu$ is the chemical potential, $U$ the on-site repulsion and $V$ the Coulomb interaction between electrons located on nearest-neighbor sites.

On the $U$-$V$ plane and at half-filling, model \eqref{eq:model} has antiferromagnetic (AF) and charge-density-wave phases separated by a normal phase~\cite{Faye:2014}. 
The parameters appropriate for graphene sheets~\cite{Wehling:2011} should fall in the latter phase, in the approximation where interactions beyond nearest-neighbor sites are neglected.
At large $U$, the model can be used for other materials, for instance the compound $\mathrm{In}_3\mathrm{Cu}_2\mathrm{V}\mathrm{O}_9$, which is known from experiments to be antiferromagnetic~\cite{Yan:2012}.


\begin{figure}
\centerline{\includegraphics[scale=0.75]{hexa}}
\caption{(Color online) Tiling of the honeycomb lattice by 6-site clusters (gray shading) used in VCA.
The three colors (red, green, blue) of the links correspond to the three different phases of the bond triplet pairing in the Kekul\'e pattern defined as {$p$+$ip$-K}\ in the text.
The A and B sublattices are indicated, as well as the three elementary vectors ${\mathbf{e}}_{1,2,3}$.}
\label{fig:hexa}
\end{figure}



\subsection{The variational cluster approximation}

In order to probe the possibility of superconductivity in model \eqref{eq:model}, we use the variational cluster approximation (VCA) with an exact diagonalization solver at zero temperature~\cite{Dahnken:2004}.
This method has been applied to many strongly correlated systems in connection with various broken symmetry phases, in particular superconductivity~\cite{Senechal:2005,Aichhorn:2006}.
For a detailed review of the method, see Refs~\cite{Potthoff:2012fk,Potthoff:2014rt}.

Like other quantum cluster methods, VCA starts by a tiling of the lattice into an infinite number of (usually identical) clusters. 
In this work, we will use the 6-site cluster shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:hexa}.
In VCA, one considers two systems: the original system described by the Hamiltonian $H$, defined on the infinite lattice, and the {\it reference system}, governed by the Hamiltonian $H'$, defined on the cluster only, with the same interaction part as $H$.
Typically, $H'$ will be a restriction of $H$ to the cluster (i.e., with inter-cluster hopping removed), to which various Weiss fields may be added in order to probe broken symmetries.
More generally, any one-body term can be added to $H'$.
The size of the cluster should be small enough for the electron Green function to be computed numerically.


The optimal one-body part of $H'$ is determined by a variational principle. More precisely, the electron self-energy ${\bm{\Sigma}}$ associated with $H'$ is used as a variational self-energy, in order to construct the following Potthoff self-energy functional~\cite{Potthoff:2003b}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\Omega[{\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi)]=\Omega^{\prime}[{\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi)]\\
\displaystyle+{\mathrm{Tr}}\ln[-({\mathbf{G}}^{-1}_{0}-{\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi))^{-1%
}]-{\mathrm{Tr}}\ln(-{\mathbf{G}}^{\prime}(\xi))" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>𝚺</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>𝚺</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>Tr</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>𝐆</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝚺</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>Tr</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>𝐆</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext:
This represents the best possible value of the self-energy ${\bm{\Sigma}}$, which is used, together with the noninteracting Green function ${\mathbf{G}}_0$, to construct an approximate Green function ${\mathbf{G}}$ for the original lattice Hamiltonian $H$.
From that Green function one can compute the average of any one-body operator, in particular order parameters associated with antiferromagnetism or superconductivity.
The actual value of $\Omega(\xi)$ at the stationary point is a good approximation to the physical grand potential of the lattice Hamiltonian $H$.

There may be more than one stationary solutions to Eq.~\eqref{eq:Euler}. For instance: A {\it normal state} solution in which all Weiss fields used to describe broken symmetries are zero, and another solution, with a non-zero Weiss field, describing a broken symmetry state. 
As an additional principle, we assert that the solution with the lowest value of the functional~\eqref{eq:omega} is the physical solution~\cite{Potthoff:2006mb}.
Thus competing phases may be compared via their value of the grand potential $\Omega$, obtained by introducing different Weiss fields. 

A formal requirement of the method is that the interaction terms are the same in $H$ and $H'$.
This cannot be true if extended interactions are included, because the tiling of the lattice into clusters breaks inter-cluster interactions.
In that case, an additional approximation is needed: the dynamical Hartree approximation~\cite{Senechal:2013bh,Faye:2014}, in which the extended interaction term in \eqref{eq:model} is replaced by
prevtext:
The quantities ${\mathbf{G}}'$ and ${\mathbf{G}}_0$ above are respectively the physical Green function of the cluster and the non-interacting Green function of the lattice. 
The symbol $\xi$ stands for a small collection of parameters that define the one-body part of $H'$. 
${\mathrm{Tr}}$ is a functional trace, i.e. a sum over frequencies, momenta and bands, and $\Omega'$ is the grand potential of the cluster, i.e. its ground state energy, since the chemical potential $\mu$ is included in the Hamiltonian.
${\mathbf{G}}'(\omega)$ and $\Omega'$ are computed numerically via the Lanczos method at zero temperature.

The Potthoff functional $\Omega[{\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi)]$ in Eq.~\eqref{eq:omega} is computed exactly, but on a restricted space of the self-energies ${\bm{\Sigma}}(\xi)$ that are the physical self-energies of the reference Hamiltonian $H'$.
We use a standard optimization method (e.g. Newton-Raphson) in the space of parameters $\xi$ to find the stationary value of $\Omega(\xi)$:

nexttext:
where $V_{{\mathbf{r}},{\mathbf{r}}'}^\mathrm{c}$ denotes the nearest-neighbor interactions between sites belonging to the same cluster and $V_{{\mathbf{r}},{\mathbf{r}}'}^\mathrm{ic}$ the interactions between sites belonging to different clusters.
In this notation the positions ${\mathbf{r}},{\mathbf{r}}'$ may be restricted the cluster, as they are folded back appropriately onto a single cluster.
The mean fields $\bar n_{\mathbf{r}}$ must be determined self-consistently via a repeated application of the VCA method.
For the 6-site cluster used in this work, if we ignore the possibility of charge order, this mean-field decomposition amounts to shifting the chemical potential. 
Thus the one-body operator added to each cluster is

The actual value of $\Omega(\xi)$ at the stationary point is a good approximation to the physical grand potential of the lattice Hamiltonian $H$.

There may be more than one stationary solutions to Eq.~\eqref{eq:Euler}. For instance: A {\it normal state} solution in which all Weiss fields used to describe broken symmetries are zero, and another solution, with a non-zero Weiss field, describing a broken symmetry state. 
As an additional principle, we assert that the solution with the lowest value of the functional~\eqref{eq:omega} is the physical solution~\cite{Potthoff:2006mb}.
Thus competing phases may be compared via their value of the grand potential $\Omega$, obtained by introducing different Weiss fields. 

A formal requirement of the method is that the interaction terms are the same in $H$ and $H'$.
This cannot be true if extended interactions are included, because the tiling of the lattice into clusters breaks inter-cluster interactions.
In that case, an additional approximation is needed: the dynamical Hartree approximation~\cite{Senechal:2013bh,Faye:2014}, in which the extended interaction term in \eqref{eq:model} is replaced by

where $n$ is the average occupation of each site and $\hat N$ is the total electron number operator on the cluster.


\subsection{Superconductivity}

The VCA is a real-space method with an emphasis on short-range correlations, because of the small size of the clusters.
In order to probe broken symmetries, one therefore introduces a set of {\it local} Weiss fields.
In particular, for superconductivity, we introduce the following nearest-neighbor, singlet and triplet pairing operators:

In this notation the positions ${\mathbf{r}},{\mathbf{r}}'$ may be restricted the cluster, as they are folded back appropriately onto a single cluster.
The mean fields $\bar n_{\mathbf{r}}$ must be determined self-consistently via a repeated application of the VCA method.
For the 6-site cluster used in this work, if we ignore the possibility of charge order, this mean-field decomposition amounts to shifting the chemical potential. 
Thus the one-body operator added to each cluster is

\subsection{Superconductivity}

The VCA is a real-space method with an emphasis on short-range correlations, because of the small size of the clusters.
In order to probe broken symmetries, one therefore introduces a set of {\it local} Weiss fields.
In particular, for superconductivity, we introduce the following nearest-neighbor, singlet and triplet pairing operators:

\downarrow}+c_{{\mathbf{r}},\downarrow}c_{{\mathbf{r}}+{\mathbf{e}}_{i},\uparrow}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>,</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>c</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>𝐞</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>,</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>c</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>𝐞</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where the three phases $\phi_j$ and the wave vector ${\mathbf{Q}}$ define the precise superconducting order. 

In this work, we will focus on the following possibilities:
\begin{enumerate}
\item A translation invariant triplet order, with phases $(\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3) = (0, 2\pi/3, 4\pi/3)$ and ${\mathbf{Q}}=0$. This defines a chiral order that we will call $p+ip$ superconductivity, following Ref.~\cite{Faye:2014}.
\item A non-chiral triplet order, with phases $(\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3) = (1, -1,0)$ and ${\mathbf{Q}}=0$, also investigated in Ref.~\cite{Faye:2014}.
\item Finally, and most important, a non-translation invariant order with phases $(\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3) = (0, 2\pi/3, 4\pi/3)$ and ${\mathbf{Q}}={\mathbf{K}}=(2\pi/3,2\pi/3\sqrt3)$ (the Dirac wave vector) that we will call the chiral Kekul\'e superconducting order, following Ref.~\cite{Roy:2010kq}, and note $p$+$ip$-K. In this configuration, all links have the same triplet pairing amplitude, but their phases vary as illustrated by three different colors on Fig.~\ref{fig:hexa}.
Luckily, the 6-site cluster used in this work is also the unit cell of this order.
\end{enumerate}
For each of these possibilities, we apply the VCA by defining the reference Hamiltonian $H'$ as follows:
prevtext:
where the nearest-neighbor vectors ${\mathbf{e}}_i$ are defined on Fig.~\ref{fig:hexa}.
From these elementary operators, one can define lattice-wide paring operators as follows:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{\Delta}^{S(T)}({\mathbf{Q}})=\sum_{{\mathbf{r}}\in A,j}\left(\hat{\Delta}%
^{S(T)}_{{\mathbf{r}},j}e^{i({\mathbf{Q}}\cdot{\mathbf{r}}+\phi_{j})}+\mathrm{%
H.c.}\right)" display="block"><mrow><msup><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>𝐐</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mrow><mi>𝐫</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msubsup><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>𝐐</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐫</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $H^{(c)}$ is the restriction of the Hamiltonian \eqref{eq:model} to the cluster and $\hat N$ is the number of electrons on the cluster.
We treat the cluster chemical potential $\mu'$ and the Weiss field $\Delta$ as variational parameters (in other words $\xi=(\mu',\Delta)$) and the VCA procedure is iterated until self-consistency is reached on the electron density $n$.

For each type of superconducting order found, we can compute the condensation energy
prevtext:
where the three phases $\phi_j$ and the wave vector ${\mathbf{Q}}$ define the precise superconducting order. 

In this work, we will focus on the following possibilities:
\begin{enumerate}
\item A translation invariant triplet order, with phases $(\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3) = (0, 2\pi/3, 4\pi/3)$ and ${\mathbf{Q}}=0$. This defines a chiral order that we will call $p+ip$ superconductivity, following Ref.~\cite{Faye:2014}.
\item A non-chiral triplet order, with phases $(\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3) = (1, -1,0)$ and ${\mathbf{Q}}=0$, also investigated in Ref.~\cite{Faye:2014}.
\item Finally, and most important, a non-translation invariant order with phases $(\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3) = (0, 2\pi/3, 4\pi/3)$ and ${\mathbf{Q}}={\mathbf{K}}=(2\pi/3,2\pi/3\sqrt3)$ (the Dirac wave vector) that we will call the chiral Kekul\'e superconducting order, following Ref.~\cite{Roy:2010kq}, and note $p$+$ip$-K. In this configuration, all links have the same triplet pairing amplitude, but their phases vary as illustrated by three different colors on Fig.~\ref{fig:hexa}.
Luckily, the 6-site cluster used in this work is also the unit cell of this order.
\end{enumerate}
For each of these possibilities, we apply the VCA by defining the reference Hamiltonian $H'$ as follows:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H^{\prime}=H^{(c)}+(\mu^{\prime}-\mu+nV)\hat{N}-3Vn^{2}+\Delta\hat{\Delta}^{(T%
)}({\mathbf{Q}})" display="block"><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>μ</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>𝐐</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

where $H^{(c)}$ is the restriction of the Hamiltonian \eqref{eq:model} to the cluster and $\hat N$ is the number of electrons on the cluster.
We treat the cluster chemical potential $\mu'$ and the Weiss field $\Delta$ as variational parameters (in other words $\xi=(\mu',\Delta)$) and the VCA procedure is iterated until self-consistency is reached on the electron density $n$.

For each type of superconducting order found, we can compute the condensation energy

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H^{\prime}_{\rm AF}=h\left\{\sum_{i\in A}(n_{i\uparrow}-n_{i\downarrow})-\sum_%
{i\in B}(n_{i\uparrow}-n_{i\downarrow})\right\}" display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mi>AF</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>↑</mo><mi/></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>↓</mo><mi/></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>↑</mo><mi/></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>↓</mo><mi/></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
